author: Katie Dangerfield
title: Community honours Cooper Nemeth, 1 year after his disappearance - Winnipeg | Globalnews.ca
text:
February 13, 2017 9:15 am Updated: February 13, 2017 3:43 pm Community honours Cooper Nemeth, 1 year after his disappearance By Katie Dangerfield Online Producer Global News 
WATCH: Support for Cooper Nemeth’s family pours in from around Winnipeg and around the world. What is this? 
Sponsored content is written by Global News' editorial staff without any editorial influence by the sponsor. If you'd like to learn more... X What is this? 
Sponsored content is written by Global News' without any editorial influence by the sponsor. If you'd like to learn more... - 
WINNIPEG — It’s been one year since Winnipeg teenager, Cooper Nemeth went missing after going to a house party in North Kildonan. 
On Monday evening his family and community are holding a memorial to honour his memory. 
The ceremony will take place at 6:30 p.m. at the Niji Mahkwa School at 450 Flora Ave. There will be an Indigenous healing ceremony and members from Winnipeg’s Bear Clan Patrol will also be present. Story continues below 
“It’s about building those bridges and taking down those barriers and this evening is evidence to that, we’re still involved,still engaged a year later so out of that tragedy comes something beautiful,” said James Favel, executive director of Bear Clan Patrol. 
Nemeth, 17, was last seen on the evening of Feb. 13. 
READ MORE: Timeline of Winnipeg teen Cooper Nemeth’s disappearance 
Family, friends and volunteers scoured the streets of all week in an attempt to find Nemeth. But on Feb. 20, family members called off the hunt for the teen, after his body was found in a bin outside a house in Valley Gardens. 
On Feb. 21, Nicholas Bell-Wright was charged with second-degree murder in connection to his death.
